instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPV5_S0: What is PPV5_S0? This is a typo of PP5V_S0 When you see PPV5_S0, assume they meant to type PP5V_S0.
definitions.P1V05S0_EN: What is P1V05S0_EN? P1V05S0_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V05_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
Hi

Computer turns on, no chime, keyboard light or video.

Tested CPU power coils 0v.

ALl SYS PWRGD 3.5v
PP3V3 S0 us 3.5v however I get no voltage at 2 of <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR> - should I replace this resistor? (CPUVR PGOOD)

Cheers

James

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
Sorry .. I realize now that there must be power coming from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> CPUVR-Pgood so the issue lies elsewhere I think?!

<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VDD</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL> 12.75v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> -.422v 
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.508v
<SIGNAL>PPVTT_SO_DDR</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> -.422v"
<SIGNAL>1V05_S0</SIGNAL> must appear before VCORE.
Check <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> area, post some basic voltages there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> - input voltages missing

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_P1V05S0_VCC</SIGNAL> 0v

Am I correct in my reading of the schematic that the supply for "<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_P1V05S0_VCC</SIGNAL>" is <SIGNAL>PPV5_S0</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7601</RESISTOR> is then burnt.
Replace it, but first check for short at  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_P1V05S0_VCC</SIGNAL>; <CAPACITOR>C7602</CAPACITOR>, or <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> may be bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
We replaced <RESISTOR>R7601</RESISTOR> and now have 5v at pin 13 

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> has 300mv.

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12V

<SIGNAL>P1VO5S0_DRVH</SIGNAL> - 300mv
..................... DRVL 0v.
.......................... LL 300mv
.....................  . VBST 5v
<SIGNAL>P1V05S0_BOOT_RC</SIGNAL> drops to 300mv after <CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>

<SIGNAL>P1V05S0_EN</SIGNAL> 5v

Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR> no change of voltage at pin2. 
 

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> Pin Output
FSEL - .5v
RTN - 0.2mv
OCSET - 300mv
VO - 400mv
SREF - 0v
FB  - 300mv
EN - 3.3V

vcc - 


-- Checked We replaced <RESISTOR>R7601</RESISTOR> again and now 0v.. has it burnt out again.. or a different issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
Why did you replace <RESISTOR>R7601</RESISTOR> again?
You've already got 5V at pin 13 after replaced it first time.

Change <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
Hi

Sorry for the long delay. I have been in hospital having my appendix removed. 

I replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, however before i had time to properly check all the output pins etc I must have shorted something because I smelt the bad smoke and now the laptop won't turn on. Looks like it's back to the drawing board on this job.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
We need some basic signals and voltages for power on sequence.
Check for short all power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
Hi Sorry for the delay in getting back to you. I put this one on the back burner.

33ma draw
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 57mc (diode mode to ground shows 001)
PPVIN S5 HS COMPUTING ISNS - 57.5mv
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V3_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 58mv
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 18.5v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - 18.5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.43v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 375mv

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
I have removed F7140 and F7141. Diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still shows 0. on <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> is approx 300.

Is the next step to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and find the warm thing?

Cheers

James

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no Brain
threads.message:
"Is the next step to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and find the warm thing?"
Really NOT!!!

Switch to ohm mode and compare <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> reading with all big coils; check CPU coils in particular.
I bet for a burnt FDMF6808 chip...
